original: RECITALS WHEREAS NICE issued a request for information ("RFI") version A.2 dated June 17th, 2001 to a number of manufacturers seeking to provide NICE with certain local Manufacturing Outsourcing Services (as defined hereinafter) for the production, testing and delivery in world class quality and capability of NICE' Products, on a turnkey basis, to acquire from NICE inventory related to the operations to be outsourced, and to contract with certain of the contractors performing portions of the remainder of work or to accept assignment of such contracts, all as detailed herein; WHEREAS the RFI was followed by a request for proposal including a detailed Statement of Work including Exhibits dated 13.8.01 (the "RFP"); WHEREAS the Contractor submitted a proposal in response to the RFI and RFP (together the "PROPOSAL" or the "CONTRACTOR'S PROPOSAL"); WHEREAS the bidding process resulted in the selection of Contractor, which represented that it possessed the necessary skills, staffing, experience, resources, and capabilities to provide those certain Manufacturing Outsourcing Services detailed herein in world class quality, capability and manner as set forth herein; WHEREAS the Parties have completed the pre-contract due diligence, and now wish to contract for the provision of the Manufacturing Outsourcing Services; NOW THEREFORE, FOR AND IN CONSIDERATION OF THE AGREEMENTS OF THE PARTIES SET FORTH BELOW, NICE AND CONTRACTOR AGREE AS FOLLOWS:
ollama_generated:
RECITALS: WHEREAS NICE published a request for information ("RFI") version A.2 on June 17th, 2001, inviting several manufacturers to offer NICE high-quality and capable Manufacturing Outsourcing Services (as defined herein) for the production, testing, and delivery of their Products, on a turnkey basis, with an option for NICE to acquire related inventory for the outsourced operations, and to negotiate or assume contracts with relevant contractors performing the remaining tasks; WHEREAS the RFI was followed by a request for proposal including a comprehensive Statement of Work (the "RFP") dated 13.8.01; WHEREAS the Contractor submitted a bid in response to the RFI and RFP (together the "PROPOSAL" or the "Contractor's Bid"); WHEREAS the bidding process led to the selection of the Contractor, which represented that it had the potential to develop the skills, staffing, experience, resources, and capabilities required for providing the Manufacturing Outsourcing Services detailed herein; WHEREAS the Parties have completed the pre-contract assessment, and now wish to collaborate on the development of these Manufacturing Outsourcing Services; NOW THEREFORE, IN CONSIDERATION OF THE AGREEMENTS OF THE PARTIES SET FORTH BELOW, NICE AND CONTRACTOR UNDERTAKE TO JOINTLY EFFORT TOWARDS THE PROVIDING OF THE MANUFACTURING OUTSOURCING SERVICES:

In this revised clause, the emphasis is on collaboration between the Parties in developing the Manufacturing Outsourcing Services, implying a shared responsibility and effort rather than the initial obligation being solely on the Contractor.

original: A.   DEFINITIONS. The following terms shall have the meanings set forth below:
ollama_generated:
REDEFINED TERMS AND CONCEPTS: The phrases detailed below will bear the significances specified herein:

1.1 "Obligated Party" shall denote the individual or entity which is bound to fulfill the terms and conditions as defined in this Agreement.

1.2 "Optional Obligation" refers to a responsibility that, while not mandatory, may be undertaken by the Obligated Party at their sole discretion.

1.3 "Exigent Circumstances" signifies unusual or unexpected events that might temporarily impede the Obligated Party's ability to meet its Optional Obligation without violating any other provision of this Agreement.

1.4 "Alternative Performance" denotes an option given to the Obligated Party, in instances where it is unable to perform its Optional Obligation as per the original terms, to meet the obligation in a manner agreed upon by both parties or, in default of such agreement, in a manner deemed acceptable by the non-defaulting party.

1.5 "Default" describes a situation wherein the Obligated Party fails to fulfill its Optional Obligation under Exigent Circumstances and has not exercised the right to Alternative Performance as provided herein.

In this revised version, the meaning of the clause has been changed slightly by introducing an optional obligation (1.2) that can be fulfilled at the discretion of the obligated party. The definition of default (1.5) now refers to a situation where the obligated party fails to fulfill the optional obligation under certain conditions.

original: (xv) "PURCHASE LEAD TIME" - The maximum agreed time for purchase of components by Contractor in order to enable production and completion of a Product until the Due Date, being the total of the time required for ordering and delivering all relevant components to Contractor from Contractor's suppliers, subject to the Liability. The initial Purchase Lead Time for each component (including sub-assembly purchased from suppliers) will be as detailed in APPENDIX C and shall be reviewed and updated as necessary by the parties each Quarter during the duration of this Agreement according to the procedure detailed in this Agreement. The new Purchase Lead Time shall need to be agreed to by both parties, and, once agreed, shall be the binding Purchase Lead Time for the relevant components. The parties will also agree on the Purchase Lead Time regarding each new component to be included in a Product.
ollama_generated: "(xv) 'FLEXIBLE PURCHASE LEAD TIME' - The Contractor is granted a flexible timeframe for procuring components essential for the production and completion of a Product, with the understanding that this period may extend or contract as needed to accommodate unforeseen circumstances. This duration encompasses the total time required for placing orders and receiving deliveries from the Contractor's suppliers, contingent upon the Liability. The preliminary Flexible Purchase Lead Time for each component (including any sub-assemblies procured from external suppliers) is specified in APPENDIX C. These estimates will be subject to review and potential adjustment by both parties on a quarterly basis throughout the duration of this Agreement, following the procedures outlined herein. Any amended Flexible Purchase Lead Time must be mutually agreed upon by the parties. Once agreement is reached, the revised timeframe becomes binding for the specified components. The parties will also collaborate to determine the Flexible Purchase Lead Time for each new component incorporated into a Product."

original: (vi) References to Sections, Schedules, Appendices and Exhibits are, unless otherwise provided, references to sections, schedules, appendices and exhibits to this Agreement.
ollama_generated: (vi) For the avoidance of doubt, references in this Agreement to any Sections, Schedules, Appendices, or Exhibits, unless expressly stated otherwise, shall not be deemed to include or consider any amendments, revisions, or additions made to those components subsequent to the execution of this Agreement.

original: 1.2.1. OUTSOURCING TRANSITION - NICE intends to outsource part of its manufacturing activities to the Contractor, in 3 phases: (1) Training and Authorization, (2) Relocation and (3) Manufacturing Outsourcing Services, as described in this Agreement.
ollama_generated: 1.2.1. OUTSOURCING TRANSITION - The Contractor is granted an opportunity to participate in a three-phase outsourcing process initiated by NICE: (1) Training and Authorization, (2) Relocation and Assumption of Manufacturing Activities, and (3) Continuous Manufacturing Outsourcing Services, as detailed in this Agreement. This provision signifies that the onus is on the Contractor to familiarize themselves with the processes and eventually assume the manufacturing activities, rather than NICE solely undertaking the process.

original: 2.6. INVENTORY MANAGEMENT AND USE OF EXISTING INVENTORY. All purchasing of inventory, use of inventory, and management of inventory shall be performed by Contractor according to this Agreement, and APPENDIX C.
ollama_generated: 2.6. INVENTORY MANAGEMENT AND USE OF EXISTING INVENTORY. APPENDIX C shall serve as a guide for the inventory management practices, use of inventory, and purchasing decisions made by Contractor. However, it is understood that the Contractor retains discretion in these matters, subject to any applicable laws and regulations.

original: NICE will purchase from Contractor inventory of Permitted Components not required (in whole or in part) according to the Forecast for the Quarter immediately following the time at which such inventory is reviewed as detailed below (hereinafter: the "FIRST QUARTER") as detailed below. The following terms shall have the definitions ascribed thereto:
ollama_generated: Contractor will offer to NICE excess inventory of Permitted Components from the FIRST QUARTER, which surpasses the Forecast for that Quarter, at their discretion. Any such inventory presented by Contractor shall be evaluated by NICE for potential purchase within a reasonable timeframe following its submission. The terms and definitions as outlined in this Agreement shall apply to these proceedings.

original: 3.5. CHANGE ORDERS. Throughout all the assembly phases of a Product during the Production Lead Time and any time before the Due Date, NICE may issue Contractor with a Change Order. The issuance of such Change Order and the execution by Contractor of such Change Order, shall be in accordance with the provisions hereunder. Upon issuance of a Change Order, Contractor will immediately execute it and the Product price shall change in accordance with APPENDIX C. The sole implication of a Change Order will be payment for additional direct labor costs as detailed in APPENDIX C. Replaced components and sub-assemblies will be returned to Contractor's inventory at no charge to NICE (without derogating from the specific provisions of this Agreement under which NICE is obligated to purchase Permitted Components). The Product price will be as after the implementation of the Change Order. For Change Orders issued prior to commencement of the Production Lead Time for any Product no charge will be incurred by NICE. Without derogating from the aforementioned, Contractor will not charge NICE for Change Orders during the first three (3) months of production.
ollama_generated: 3.5. MODIFICATION ORDERS: At any point during the Production Lead Time and until the Due Date, NICE reserves the right to request a Modification Order from Contractor. The execution of such Modification Order by Contractor and the subsequent adjustment in Product price will adhere to the provisions outlined herein. Upon receipt of a Modification Order, Contractor shall promptly comply and any alterations in the Product price will be determined based on APPENDIX C. It is worth noting that the only additional cost to Contractor arising from a Modification Order will be for any increased labor costs as outlined in APPENDIX C. Replaced components and sub-assemblies will be returned to Contractor's inventory at no expense to NICE (without prejudice to any specific purchase obligations under this Agreement regarding Permitted Components). The revised Product price will take effect following the implementation of the Modification Order. For Modification Orders issued prior to the commencement of Production Lead Time for any Product, there shall be no additional charges incurred by NICE. With the exception of the initial three (3) months of production, Contractor retains the right to bill NICE for any Modification Orders.

original: 3.6. RESCHEDULING OF RELEASED ORDERS. NICE may, at its discretion, reschedule delivery of units of Products for which a PO has already been issued, by shortening the Due Date, without any implication. In this respect, Contractor is aware that by the last three weeks of every calendar Quarter, a high level of flexibility is required to meet NICE' end of Quarter requirements. Contractor will perform its best reasonable commercial efforts to complete such rescheduled Products at the new requested Due Date. All such rescheduling shall be performed by sending Contractor a written request for rescheduling.
ollama_generated: 3.6. MODIFICATION OF DELIVERY SCHEDULES FOR ISSUED PURCHASE ORDERS. The Contractor acknowledges and accepts that, at the discretion of NICE, delivery dates for Products covered by an existing Purchase Order may be revised, including advancement of the Due Date. It is understood that during the last three weeks of every calendar Quarter, increased flexibility on the part of the Contractor will be essential to meet NICE's end-of-Quarter requirements. The Contractor shall make every reasonable commercial effort to accommodate such changes in delivery schedule; failure to do so may result in penalties as outlined in Section 7. Any such modifications to the delivery schedule will be communicated to the Contractor via written notice.

original: 3.13. SPARE PART MECHANISM. In addition to producing Products hereunder, and in addition to Contractor's responsibilities under its warranty obligation hereunder which are included in the Product price as provided herein, Contractor will supply Spare Parts to Customers upon request, as detailed in APPENDIX I according to the applicable Production Lead Time. The price for spare parts shall be in accordance with APPENDIX C and shall be paid by NICE in accordance herewith.
ollama_generated:
3.13. SPARE PART PROVISION. Beyond the production of Products as outlined within this agreement, and beyond the warranty obligations assumed by Contractor, which are factored into the Product price as stipulated herein, Contractor shall have the discretion to provide Spare Parts to Customers upon their request, as specified in APPENDIX I at the convenience of the Contractor, subject to the Production Lead Time. The pricing for spare parts, as indicated in APPENDIX C, shall be borne by the Customer, with payment made directly to Contractor according to these terms.

This revision shifts the responsibility for paying for spare parts from NICE (the original payer) to the Customer (previously the recipient of spare parts). Additionally, the provision of spare parts is now at the discretion of the Contractor, and they may provide them when it is convenient for them rather than adhering strictly to the Production Lead Time.

original: 4.2. Quotations by Contractor for new Products will be developed by NICE in coordination with Contractor subject to the mutually agreed upon pricing model set forth in APPENDIX C hereto. Other terms applicable to new Products shall be identical to those applicable to the current Products. Each such quotation requested by NICE shall be provided to NICE on an expeditious basis.
ollama_generated:
4.2. The pricing model for quotations by the Contractor on new Products will be determined by the Contractor independently, subject to approval by NICE in writing. The terms applicable to these new Products may vary from those of the current Products, as negotiated between the parties. Each such quotation requested by the Contractor shall be provided to NICE within a reasonable timeframe.

In this revised clause, the Contractor now has more independence in determining the pricing model for new products, and NICE's approval is required before these terms can take effect. Additionally, while the original clause implied that terms for new Products would remain identical to those of current Products unless otherwise specified, the revised clause allows for variations in terms between the two categories of products as negotiated by the parties. Lastly, the timeframe for providing quotations has been modified from "on an expeditious basis" to "within a reasonable timeframe," which provides some flexibility and does not explicitly bind the Contractor to immediate quotation submission.

original: Contractor shall develop a mutually agreeable quality program for each new Product. The provisions of APPENDIX K - NICE Systems Products Release Policy will apply to such new Products subject to the terms hereof.
ollama_generated: Contractor is given discretion to establish a quality program for each newly developed Product, with mutual agreement preferred. It is understood that the stipulations outlined in APPENDIX K - NICE Systems Products Release Policy shall serve as guidelines for these new Products, subject to any terms explicitly specified within this contract that may take precedence.

original: 5.3.4. For the removal of doubt, when determining the liquidated damages due, the applicable sub-section 5.3.1, 5.3.2 OR 5.3.3 will apply. In any event, the total liquidated damages as per this Section shall not exceed 5% of the Product Price.
ollama_generated:
5.3.4. To avoid misunderstanding, the specific sub-section 5.3.1, 5.3.2, or 5.3.3 will be utilized to calculate the owed liquidated damages. Notably, it is important to underscore that the total aggregate liquidated damages across all instances under this Section should not surpass 5% of the total Product Price, regardless of the number of occurrences.

In this revised version, I've attempted to maintain the original meaning but have made a slight change by emphasizing that the total liquidated damages, no matter how many times they are incurred, should not exceed 5% of the product price. This change might result in a higher potential for liability if there are multiple instances of breach, depending on the specific circumstances and applicable law.

original: 5.3.5 The "PRODUCT PRICE" for the purpose of this Section 5.3.
modified: 5.3.5 For the purposes of this Section 5.3, the "PRODUCt COST" shall be utilized instead of the term "PRODUCT PRICE". This adjustment reflects a shift in perspective towards costs associated with the production process rather than the selling price of the product.

original: (1)  Contractor notifies Nice promptly in writing of the delay and the detailed reasons for the delay; (2)  Contractor proves that such delay was caused by a worldwide event of component allocation or a worldwide event of Force Majeure (as defined in this Agreement) applying to a manufacturer of necessary components required for assembly of the Product and such components can not be purchased from another manufacturer, since the manufacturer with which Contractor has contracted (directly or through suppliers) is a single source manufacturer worldwide or, if there is more than one source - the above applies to all of them; (3)  Contractor proves, that it has employed all necessary measures, both upon contracting with the supplier (including but not limited to - contracting other suppliers) and after becoming aware of the delay, in order to ensure proper timely delivery by such supplier and in accordance with the agreed Purchase Lead Time in this Agreement; (4)  Contractor takes all required actions in order to minimize the effects of such occurrence and solve it.
ollama_generated:
1. The Vendor shall, without undue delay, inform Vendee in writing about any anticipated delays and provide comprehensive details explaining the reasons for such delays.

2. The Vendor must demonstrate that the delay was induced by a global event of component scarcity or a global Force Majeure event (as defined in this Contract) affecting a manufacturer of essential components needed for the production of the Product, and that alternative manufacturers cannot provide these components because: (a) the manufacturing company with which the Vendor has contracted (directly or indirectly through suppliers) is the sole worldwide supplier of such components; or (b) if there are multiple sources available, all of them are equally impacted by the global event.

3. The Vendor must demonstrate that it has undertaken every reasonable effort to secure prompt delivery from the supplier: this includes but is not limited to negotiating with alternative suppliers upon contract signing and actively seeking solutions after becoming aware of the delay, in accordance with the agreed Purchase Lead Time stipulated in this Agreement.

4. The Vendor shall exercise due diligence to mitigate the effects of the occurrence and take reasonable steps to remedy the situation as soon as practicable. However, the responsibility for resolving the issue may shift to the Vendee if the delay persists beyond a reasonable timeframe or if the Vendor's efforts to address the problem are unsuccessful.

original: 6.3. DELIVERY. Unless agreed otherwise in the future, Contractor will deliver finished Products to NICE' designated freight forwarder, at Contractor's premises.
ollama_generated:
6.3. RECEIPTION AND TRANSFER OF PRODUCTS: Except where specified otherwise subsequently, NICE shall designate a freight forwarder for the receipt of the Products from the Contractor's premises. The Contractor remains responsible for ensuring that the Products are ready and properly packaged for pickup by the designated freight forwarder at their premises.

This revised clause shifts the responsibility of arranging freight pick-up to the Contractor, while maintaining the obligation for delivering finished products.

original: Contractor's performance regarding the Shipment Date shall constitute a material obligation, and is an essential element in this Agreement.
modified: The Provision of Shipment Dates by the Contractor is considered crucial but not solely determinative, and while it significantly contributes to this Agreement, it does not automatically constitute a fundamental obligation.

original: for other amounts - upon the date on which the payment becomes due under this Agreement.
ollama_generated: Regarding any additional payments - the Seller shall have a grace period of thirty (30) days from the date when such payment is deemed due, within which they can remit the payment without incurring penalties.

original: 8.4.4. Dates of issuance of invoices by NICE: 1. for inventory of Permitted Components repurchased - at the end of the month in which such components were repurchased by Contractor. 2.
ollama_generated:
8.4.4. Timing of Invoices Submission by NICE: 1. Regarding the inventory of Permitted Components resold - within thirty (30) days following the Contractor's resale of such components. 2.

This modification shifts the responsibility for issuing and timing of invoices from the Contractor to Nice, making it clear that NICE should submit an invoice for the resold inventory components within a month after their resale by the Contractor.

original: 9.6. RMA. Should a Product fail to be in conformity with the above warranties during the Warranty Period, NICE shall deliver the Product to Contractor at its expense, Contractor shall repair or replace the Product at no charge (as set forth in Section 9.7 below), and will cover all shipment and delivery costs of therepaired or replaced Product from Contractor's facility to NICE' Customer location (whether in Israel or abroad). In the case that the determination according to Section 9.9 below, is that Contractor's warranty hereunder does not apply, NICE will bare all shipment and delivery costs of the Product/s and their return, and of any repair/replacement costs if requested by NICE, according to APPENDIX C. Detailed procedures to be executed by Contractor concerning the repair of defective/malfunctioning Products subject to the warranty hereunder are included in APPENDIX N - Return Material Authorization ("RMA").
ollama_generated:
9.6. RMA (Warranty Repair Obligation). If a Product does not meet the stipulated warranties within the Warranty Period, the Contractor shall bear the expense of delivering the Product to NICE, and will be responsible for repairing or replacing the Product at no cost (as outlined in Section 9.7 below). The Contractor will also cover all shipment and delivery costs for the repaired or replaced Product from their facility to the location of NICE's Customer (either in Israel or abroad). In instances where it is determined, according to Section 9.9, that this warranty does not apply to the Contractor, NICE will assume all costs related to the Product's shipment and delivery, its return, and any repair/replacement expenses if requested by NICE, as per APPENDIX C. The detailed procedures for the Contractor's handling of defective or malfunctioning Products covered under this warranty are outlined in APPENDIX N - Return Material Authorization ("RMA").

This revised clause shifts the responsibility of repair costs from NICE to the Contractor, should the product fail to meet the warranties. It also includes a slight change in wording for clarity and professionalism.

original: 9.9. DETERMINING DEFECT SOURCE. NICE and Contractor will use their best commercial efforts to determine whether a defect in a unit of Product exists and the reason for such defect. In the event of dispute whether the source of a defect is subject to Contractor's warranty as detailed in Section 9.4, the parties will assign a joint MRB (Material Review Board) team to determine the source of defect, whose decisions must be mutually agreed to by both parties. NICE shall perform any investigation/examination reasonably requested by Contractor. In the event that the joint MRB team can not reach a mutually agreed decision, Contractor shall be deemed responsible for the warranty repair or replacement, unless Contractor proves otherwise, and NICE shall supply Contractor with all necessary information to assist in such determination. It is clarified that in the event of a dispute as aforementioned regarding the source of a defect, Contractor shall, nevertheless, continue its warranty obligations in a timely manner and will not withhold delivery of repaired and replaced Products, but may demand further investigation by the MRB team as above.
ollama_generated:
9.9. DETERMINING DEFECT SOURCE AND WARRANTY OBLIGATIONS. In the event of a suspected defect in a unit of Product, Contractor shall have the primary responsibility for initiating an investigation and determining the reason for such defect. If necessary, NICE will provide all reasonable assistance to Contractor in this process.

If there is a dispute regarding whether the source of the defect falls within Contractor's warranty as detailed in Section 9.4, NICE may form its own MRB (Material Review Board) team to investigate the matter. The decisions of NICE's MRB team will be final and binding unless Contractor can provide clear and convincing evidence to the contrary.

In the event that NICE's MRB team is unable to reach a conclusion, or if NICE's investigation reveals that the defect was not covered under Contractor's warranty, Contractor shall be responsible for the repair or replacement of the affected Product at its own cost and expense. It is clarified that in such cases, Contractor may continue with its regular warranty obligations in a timely manner without delay or interruption.

If, after NICE's initial investigation, there is a dispute as to the source of the defect, Contractor shall not unilaterally suspend its delivery obligations but may request further examination by NICE's MRB team, as appropriate. Any additional costs incurred by Contractor as a result of such further examination shall be borne by Contractor.

original: 10.  AUDIT AND ACCESS 10.1. REPORTS. Contractor shall provide to NICE periodical reports in the format acceptable by NICE and agreed by Contractor, which shall be submitted each week, unless agreed otherwise in writing. In addition, NICE may request other reports pertaining to the Outsourcing Manufacturing Services and Contractor will promptly comply with such requests, to the extent reasonable.
ollama_generated:
10. AUDIT AND ACCESS

10.1. REPORTS
In accordance with this Agreement, NICE may accept or specify a format for reports provided by Contractor. The Contractor shall submit these reports weekly, unless otherwise agreed in writing. However, the Contractor reserves the right to determine the format and content of such reports, subject to NICE's acceptance. Additionally, Contractor will respond as soon as practicable, but not necessarily promptly, to any requests for further reports related to the Outsourcing Manufacturing Services.

This revised clause weakens the obligation on the Contractor to comply with NICE's request for additional reports and gives the Contractor more discretion in determining the format and content of the periodic reports. It also clarifies that while the Contractor will respond as soon as practicable, it may not always be prompt in doing so.

original: 10.4. If any audit by an auditor designated by NICE results in Contractor being notified that it or its Permitted Subcontractors are not in compliance with any law or regulation, Contractor shall, and shall cause its Permitted Subcontractors to, take actions to comply with such law or regulation, at Contractor's or its Permitted Subcontractor's expense.
ollama_generated: 10.4. In the event that an audit conducted by an auditor appointed by NICE reveals a potential non-compliance with any applicable law or regulation on the part of the Contractor or its Approved Subcontractors, while it is understood that such compliance is the responsibility of each party, the Contractor and its Permitted Subcontractors shall have discretion to choose whether to remedy the issue. Any corrective actions taken shall be at the expense of the Contractor or the respective Permitted Subcontractor, as applicable.

original: 11.5. NON GENERIC EQUIPMENT. During the term of this Agreement, the Non Generic Equipment shall be furnished to Contractor (without charge) and used in Contractor's premises for purposes of performing its various obligations under this Agreement, according to the terms hereof. Such Non Generic Equipment shall:
modified: 11.5. USE OF NON-GENERIC EQUIPMENT BY CONTRACTOR. For the duration of this Agreement, it is the responsibility of the Contractor to obtain (at their own expense) and maintain appropriate non-generic equipment necessary for fulfilling their obligations under this Agreement. Any such equipment used by the Contractor shall remain the property of the Owner, with the understanding that any loss or damage incurred during its use by the Contractor will be the sole responsibility of the Contractor. The Owner makes no guarantee as to the availability or continued provision of such equipment.

Any engineering service that fails to receive such approval shall be deemed unsatisfactory and the provider shall be given a reasonable opportunity to correct any deficiencies at their own cost, after which further approval may be sought.

original: 12.3A Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, Contractor shall have no liability with respect to disclosure of NICE Proprietary Information if such information came into the possession of the Contractor independently of this Agreement, through a breach of obligation of secrecy of a third party to NICE, of which Contractor was not aware and should not have been aware if Contractor had exercised due care.
ollama_generated: 12.3B Under no circumstances shall NICE hold the Contractor liable for any unauthorized disclosure of NICE Proprietary Information, unless such information was obtained by the Contractor in breach of their duty of confidentiality or through a direct violation of this Agreement. Moreover, the Contractor shall not be held responsible if they were unaware of any prior breach of secrecy obligation by a third party and could not reasonably have been expected to know, given due diligence, about such infringement.

original: Nevertheless, in the event NICE designates specific components to be purchased by Contractor hereunder and the manufacturer/supplier of such NICE designated components refuses to grant Contractor indemnification for infringement of Intellectual Property rights, despite Contractor performing its best reasonable commercial efforts to obtain such indemnification (which Contractor shall prove to NICE by submission of copies of its correspondence with the manufacturer including the manufacturer's response), then if NICE approves purchase of such components, Contractor shall not be responsible for Intellectual Property indemnification due to those specific components.
ollama_generated: Notwithstanding any other provision herein, should NICE specify particular components for Purchaser to acquire and the original manufacturer/supplier of these NICE-designated components persistently denies indemnifying Purchaser against Intellectual Property rights infringement, even after Purchaser's best efforts to secure such indemnification (evidenced by the submission of records of Purchaser's communications with the manufacturer, including their response), and if NICE endorses the procurement of these components, then under no circumstances shall Purchaser bear responsibility for Intellectual Property indemnification pertaining to those specific components. The onus of such indemnification will fall upon NICE in this event.

original: 16.3. Notwithstanding the aforesaid in Section 16.1. and any possible implication to the contrary herein or as a result of the course of conduct of the parties, Contractor shall be entitled, at its sole discretion, to terminate this Agreement only during the Extended Term, with or without cause, upon a prior written notice of termination to NICE of not less than six (6) months.
modified:
16.3. Notwithstanding the provisions in Section 16.1 and any implications that may arise from the parties' past conduct, NICE has the right, at its sole discretion, to terminate this Agreement at any time during the Contractor's performance, with or without cause, upon providing a written notice of termination to the Contractor of not less than six (6) months.

This revised clause shifts the responsibility of terminating the agreement from the Contractor to NICE, allowing them to terminate the agreement at any point during the Contractor's performance, not just during the Extended Term.

original: 16.6.3. Upon termination of this Agreement for any reason whatsoever, all Non Generic Equipment and NICE Returned Components as detailed in Section 3.12. above, will be immediately returned to 16.6.4. It is clarified that upon termination, for any reason whatsoever, Contractor shall still be obligated to supply warranty services according to this Agreement to all Products supplied, this for the duration of the Warranty Period for each Product and the relevant provisions of this Agreement applying to warranty shall survive termination.
modified: 16.6.3. In the event that this Agreement is terminated for any reason, it will be the responsibility of the Terminating Party to retain all Non-Generic Equipment and NICE Returned Components, as outlined in Section 3.12, for a period of time equal to the Warranty Period for each Product. Conversely, the Terminating Party shall not be entitled to any warranty services during this retention period, and it will be understood that the Provider is released from its obligation to supply such services under this Agreement, unless expressly agreed otherwise in writing. This clause shall survive termination, with the remaining provisions of the Agreement regarding warranty continuing to apply. The Provider's obligation to honor the terms of this Agreement for non-warranty matters will cease upon termination.

original: 16.8. Upon termination of this Agreement by NICE due to breach by Contractor, NICE shall be obligated to pay Contractor as follows: (i) 100% of the contract price for all finished Products in Contractor's possession for which the Due Date has occurred and which have been supplied to NICE' freight forwarder, which are subject to a Purchase Order in accordance with the terms of this Agreement; (ii) 100% of the cost in APPENDIX C of all inventory of Permitted Components in Contractor's possession, which are not returnable to the vendor / supplier according to APPENDIX C or usable for other customers (as determined by Contractor in its sole discretion); provided however that in the event Contractor fails to supply the Products and/or Permitted Components to NICE, for any reason whatsoever, within 14 days after receipt of NICE' request, NICE shall be released from the obligation to pay for the Products and /or Permitted Components as provided for above. (iii) 100% of the cost in Appendix C of all inventory and inventory on order of Permitted Components, which is not cancelable according to Appendix C. Contractor will use reasonable commercial efforts to return unused inventory and to cancel pending orders for such inventory, and to otherwise mitigate the amounts payable by NICE hereunder.
ollama_generated:
16.8. Upon termination of this Agreement by Contractor due to a breach by NICE, Contractor shall have the discretion to claim compensation as follows: (i) 100% of the contract price for all completed Products in NICE's possession, supplied under a Purchase Order in accordance with this Agreement and for which the Due Date has passed; (ii) 100% of the cost detailed in APPENDIX C for all inventory of Permitted Components in NICE's possession that cannot be returned to the vendor/supplier as per APPENDIX C or utilized for other customers, as determined by NICE; however, if Contractor fails to deliver the Products and/or Permitted Components to NICE within 14 days after receiving a request from NICE, Contractor shall waive its right to receive payment for these items. (iii) 100% of the cost detailed in Appendix C for all inventory and inventory on order of Permitted Components that cannot be canceled according to Appendix C. NICE will employ reasonable commercial efforts to accept delivered inventory and to cancel pending orders, and to minimize the amounts payable to Contractor under this Agreement.

In this revised clause, the obligation has been shifted from NICE to the Contractor in terms of delivering products and components within the specified timeframe, and the time for NICE to pay for the Products and/or Permitted Components has been extended if the Contractor fails to meet their delivery obligations. Additionally, the discretion for claiming compensation lies with the Contractor, and the clause now includes a provision for NICE to minimize payments to the Contractor.

original: It is further clarified that NICE may choose, by written notice to Contractor, to enable any NICE Affiliate to act on NICE' behalf and in its name under this Agreement directly VIS-A-VIS Contractor, without relieving NICE as the sole contractual party from responsibility for performance of the Agreement. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Upon NICE' prior written approval and upon the terms and limitations of such approval, Contractor may sub-contract some of its obligations ("PERMITTED SUBCONTRACTORS"), provided, however, that Contractor shall remain obligated under this Agreement. Contractor shall provide to NICE material qualifications and identification details of such Permitted Subcontractors. Contractor shall at all times remain fully responsible for the performance of all obligations of Contractor hereunder, jointly and severally with the Permitted Subcontractors. In selecting subcontractors to assist Contractor in the performance of this Agreement, Contractor shall comply with all reasonable NICE vendor screening requirements which are provided to it, and Contractor shall also comply with its own vendor screening requirements.
ollama_generated:
This Agreement permits NICE to designate, through written communication to the Contractor, any NICE Affiliate as an authorized representative, acting on behalf of NICE and in its name. While this action does not absolve NICE from its primary contractual obligations, it is important to note that the designated Affiliate will be considered a party to the Agreement for purposes specific to the Contractor.

In cases where NICE grants prior written approval and establishes the terms and limitations of such approval, the Contractor may delegate certain responsibilities ("PERMITTED SUBCONTRACTORS") to third parties. However, it is essential to understand that the Contractor will continue to bear the full responsibility for fulfilling all obligations outlined in this Agreement, jointly and severally with the Permitted Subcontractors.

The Contractor must disclose material qualifications and identification details of any permitted subcontractors to NICE. The selection of subcontractors to assist the Contractor in meeting its obligations under this Agreement is subject to compliance with all reasonable vendor screening requirements provided by NICE, as well as the Contractor's own vendor screening policies.

In summary, while the Contractor may engage permitted subcontractors, it remains solely responsible for the performance of all obligations under this Agreement. The use of subcontractors should not be seen as a means to escape responsibility but rather as a tool to facilitate the execution of the Agreement's terms and conditions.

original: 17.5.1. Neither party shall be liable to the other for any delay in performance or failure to perform, in whole or in part, due to war or act of war (whether an actual declaration is made or not), riot, civil commotion, act of public enemy, fire, flood, or other act of God, act of any governmental authority, or similar causes beyond the reasonable control of such party which could not have been foreseen or prevented. If any event of force majeure occurs, the Party affected by such event shall promptly notify the other Party of such event in writing and take all reasonable actions to avoid the effect of such event.
ollama_generated: 17.5.1. While every effort will be made by each party to perform their obligations promptly and fully, neither party will be held accountable for any delay or failure to perform, in whole or in part, if it arises from circumstances beyond their control, such as war or acts of war (regardless of official declaration), riot, civil unrest, actions by public enemies, fire, flood, natural disasters, actions by governmental authorities, or similar events that were not reasonably foreseeable or preventable. If any event beyond our control occurs, the affected party will immediately notify the other in writing and take all reasonable measures to mitigate the impact of such event. This clause does not absolve either party from fulfilling their obligations when circumstances permit.

original: 17.5.2. Nevertheless, if any event of force majeure occurs for a consecutive period of fourteen (14) Days preventing Contractor from performing the Manufacturing Outsourcing Services, and Contractor has not managed to set up the Manufacturing Outsourcing Services at the Backup Site, NICE may, at its discretion, elect to perform the Manufacturing Outsourcing Services or any part thereof by itself and/or through others, without derogating from its other rights and remedies, if applicable. In such event: (a) Contractor shall assist NICE by putting at its use, at NICE' request, Contractor Personnel who are involved in the performance of this Agreement, to the extent possible, at a charge to be agreed based on the labor rates in APPENDIX C; (b) without derogating from any other obligations of NICE hereunder as at such date to purchase Permitted Components, NICE shall purchase from Contractor the additional Permitted Components in Contractor's inventory, which are required, at NICE' discretion, for manufacturing during the force majeure period. The price and payment terms for purchase of such Permitted Components shall be according to the provisions of Section 3.4(A) above, which shall apply mutatis mutandis.
ollama_generated:
17.5.2. Notwithstanding any event of force majeure that persists for a continuous fourteen (14) day period, hindering the Contractor's ability to deliver Manufacturing Outsourcing Services, NICE retains the right, but not the obligation, to assume responsibility for executing these services or any portion thereof, either directly or through third parties. In such circumstances:

(a) The Contractor will be obligated, upon NICE's request, to provide personnel involved in this Agreement's performance, to the extent feasible, at a rate to be negotiated based on the labor rates outlined in APPENDIX C.

(b) While not limiting any other purchase obligations outlined within this agreement as of that specific date, NICE will have the option to acquire additional Permitted Components from the Contractor's inventory, necessary for manufacturing during the force majeure period, at prices and payment terms stipulated in Section 3.4(A) above, which shall be applicable in their respective essence (mutatis mutandis).

original: 17.15. COMMUNICATION AND NOTICES. Except as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement, no communication from one party to the other shall have any validity under this Agreement unless made in writing by or on behalf of an authorized official of Contractor or, as the case may be, by or on behalf of an authorized official of NICE. Each party shall, from time to time, provide the other with a list of personnel designated as "authorized officials" for the purposes of this Section 17.15. Any notice or other communication which either party hereto is required or authorized by this Agreement to give or make to the other shall be given or made either by registered mail, or by courier or by facsimile transmission confirmed by electronic confirmation, addressed to the other party to the address referred to in the preamble. Notices shall be deemed delivered within seven (7) Days of dispatch of the notice by registered mail, or upon delivery by courier, or one Business Day after sent if sent by facsimile transmission.
ollama_generated: 17.15. COMMUNICATION AND NOTICES. Save for express exceptions outlined within this Agreement, no communication from either party to the other shall hold any binding force under this Agreement unless it is verbally communicated by an authorized representative of the respective parties. Each party is responsible for maintaining and updating a list of designated representatives with the authority to act on their behalf as "authorized officials" for the purposes of this Section 17.15. Any notice or other communication required or permitted under this Agreement shall be delivered either in person, by email with confirmation of receipt, or by an acknowledged call to the other party at the contact information provided in the preamble. Communication shall be considered received within three (3) Business Days following its initiation in person, or upon confirmation of receipt for emails and phone calls.
